Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: A brief encounter in the corridor leads to a simple hello and smile.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: I was locking up my register at the end of a long shift, counting bills and double-checking receipts, when I heard a familiar voice. My neighbor, Mrs. Lee, was in line, waiting to buy a few groceries. Just this morning, we’d exchanged a cheerful hello in the corridor, and I’d promised myself to always be friendly and polite, as a good neighbor should. Now, as she approached my counter, I felt the weight of my other role pressing in. As a cashier, especially at closing time, I had to focus—every cent had to be accounted for, every transaction perfect. Mrs. Lee smiled warmly, expecting the same friendliness I’d shown earlier, but my mind was racing with numbers and procedures. I could sense her waiting for a bit of small talk, maybe a joke or a kind word, but I was torn. If I let my guard down, I might make a costly mistake. If I stayed focused, I risked seeming cold or unfriendly. My hands hovered over the register, my heart caught between the expectations of a good neighbor and a responsible cashier, unsure which role to let guide me.
